Yesterday was both Memorial Day and #MentalHealthMonday, so I want our servicemembers to know that help is available.

Veterans experiencing a mental health crisis can call 988 or visit http://VeteransCrisisLine.net to get FREE care at any VA location‚Äîregardless of insurance status.

Memorial Day can trigger PTSD, survivor's guilt, and suicidal thoughts for many veterans.

And for the families of fallen soldiers, it can be a painful reminder of their loss.

üßµ This weekend, I spent a lot of time thinking about our servicemembers and the unique struggles they face.

While it‚Äôs important to honor our heroes, Memorial Day can also bring on difficult feelings and memories for veterans.
https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/psychiatrys-think-tank/202305/not-just-bbqs-and-parades-memorial-day-can-be-painful

And only in DC is a bill clawing back small amounts of unspent COVID funds considered a cut. 

They tell us this bill cuts $41b in its first year; about the same amount as the unspent COVID funds. Pretty convenient. Also not a cut.
Some say there will be a $2T deficit in 6 years, but that CBO guesstimate relies on spending caps that do not exist and are not binding in any way in this deal.
The bill doesn‚Äôt actually set a debt limit. Rather it suspends the debt limit entirely until Jan. 2, 2025 and there is no actual amount capping the debt ceiling.

This deal keeps that record high spending intact and makes it the baseline for all spending. 

Wild.

Govt grew massively over the past 3 years. This growth was supposed to be emergency funding only during COVID. During this time, govt grew 40% or by $2 trillion from 2019 to 2023. We went from spending just over $4T to spending just over $6T.

After factoring in a small cut to discretionary spending over the next 2 yrs, we are still talking about ~$6T more or less in spending bc of large increases in spending elsewhere.

In other words, it‚Äôs a wash spending-wise.

Let‚Äôs dive into the bill:

This ‚Äúdeal‚Äù normalizes record high spending started during the pandemic. It sets these historically high spending levels as the baseline for all future spending. The bill then grows govt even more each year at about ~1%.

For these reasons and more, I will be voting NO on the Biden-McCarthy proposal to raise our nation‚Äôs Debt Ceiling.  I urge my Republican colleagues to do the same.

Adding another $4 trillion to the national debt in exchange for spending cuts that amount to a rounding error will condemn your children and mine to generations of untold debt.  If we don‚Äôt stand up to the Biden Administration now, then when?
The concessions made by the Speaker in his negotiations with President Biden fall far short of my expectations and the expectations of my friends and neighbors in Congressional District 38.

Many of us knew that this legislation would not make it into law during Biden‚Äôs tenure, but conservatives believed that in this struggle to raise our nation‚Äôs debt ceiling, we would force this administration to come to the table and compromise.  It was our way of keeping our word‚Ä¶ https://twitter.com/i/web/status/1663514469799018496
In our first 100 days, Republicans delivered on historic legislation in the House of Representatives.
I did so because I believe it was critical for our party to be united so that we could quickly get to the work of the American people.
As many of you know, shortly after the premature birth of my son, I flew back to Washington to cast a deciding vote making Kevin McCarthy the Speaker of the House on the 15th round.
I have three small children at home.  I fought in combat to preserve a future for my children and yours.
A deal that will extend the debt limit until January 2025, essentially kicking the can down the road for two more years, doesn‚Äôt hold government accountable.
A deal on the Debt Ceiling that doesn‚Äôt include a vast portion of H.R. 1, which restores American Energy Dominance, doesn‚Äôt hold government accountable.
A deal on the Debt Ceiling that doesn‚Äôt defund Biden‚Äôs new army of IRS agents doesn‚Äôt hold government accountable.
A deal on the Debt Ceiling that concedes our ability to leverage border security during the worse border crisis in our history doesn‚Äôt hold government accountable.

Joe Biden has the lowest approval rating of any President in 80 years.  He is the weakest President in generations.  We can do better than make concessions to an Administration that has lost the confidence of nearly 70% of America.

Washington is, was and always will be lousy at responsibly spending your tax dollars. 

That won‚Äôt change unless we demand change.

63% of Americans want Congress to cut spending as part of a debt ceiling deal. This bill doesn‚Äôt do that. 

Unacceptable.

And just a friendly reminder, debt ceilings are about future outlays, about future spending, and how it will be financed. It‚Äôs not about past spending or past obligations from one Administration to another.

Let that sink in.
Fully funds every spending request by the Administration (pretty much).

A continuing resolution at 99% in Section 102 only applies to discretionary and provides ample time for an omnibus should all else fail. 

While we like the intent here, it‚Äôs like a Penny Plan for discretionary, but once again, bc of how it‚Äôs written, it‚Äôs meaningless.
Manchin‚Äôs carve out for his pipeline is not germane to the bill. This is just your run of the mill govt picking winners and losers in the market and business as usual in Washington. üôÉ
Work requirements for SNAP moved from age 50 to 54 and student loan forgiveness EO repeal never happened. Not sure why anyone even bothered here.

A $1.4b cut to the IRS doesn‚Äôt equal $80b in cuts to the IRS. Nor does it mean we are ‚Äúgutting‚Äù the IRS or its 87k new hires.

Allegedly there will be $10b cut off top for 2024 during the approps process. But it‚Äôs not in the bill. That money can be cut anywhere the IRS decides.

Pay-as-you-go has some fine print under Section 265 everyone should read. The OMB director has sole waiver authority to spend if it‚Äôs "necessary for program delivery.‚Äù So that one line wipes out PAYGO.

These words on paper are totally meaningless if you read the fine print.
And on that note, do we really think the states will send back unspent COVID funds or will they find a way to use the money so they don't have to send it back?

And only in DC is a bill clawing back small amounts of unspent COVID funds considered a cut. 

They tell us this bill cuts $41b in its first year; about the same amount as the unspent COVID funds. Pretty convenient. Also not a cut.
Some say there will be a $2T deficit in 6 years, but that CBO guesstimate relies on spending caps that do not exist and are not binding in any way in this deal.
The bill doesn‚Äôt actually set a debt limit. Rather it suspends the debt limit entirely until Jan. 2, 2025 and there is no actual amount capping the debt ceiling.

This deal keeps that record high spending intact and makes it the baseline for all spending. 

Wild.

Govt grew massively over the past 3 years. This growth was supposed to be emergency funding only during COVID. During this time, govt grew 40% or by $2 trillion from 2019 to 2023. We went from spending just over $4T to spending just over $6T.

After factoring in a small cut to discretionary spending over the next 2 yrs, we are still talking about ~$6T more or less in spending bc of large increases in spending elsewhere.

In other words, it‚Äôs a wash spending-wise.

This ‚Äúdeal‚Äù normalizes record high spending started during the pandemic. It sets these historically high spending levels as the baseline for all future spending. The bill then grows govt even more each year at about ~1%.

Washington is broken. 

After reading the bill, twice, I‚Äôm voting NO on the debt ceiling debacle because playing the DC game isn‚Äôt worth selling out our kids and grandkids. 

Republicans got outsmarted by a President who can‚Äôt find his pants.

Let‚Äôs dive in.  (thread)
